direction.raw_text: The barn is unpainted except for hand lettering that says "McCawley Crop Dusting." Another plane noise, this one made by kids, brings us to TWO BOYS, sitting in the shell of an old plane propped on crates, scavenged of it's engine, seats, and wheels. The boys sit in it's cockpit, butts crowded onto the nail keg they've replaced the seat with.  They've even attached a 2x4 as propeller, as if their imaginations needed any help.  They wear overalls and have bowl haircuts:  RAFE and DANNY, 10 years old.

direction.raw_text: Their vocal motors roar again... But a man's hand grabs Danny by the straps of his overalls and jerks him from the cockpit. He's also missing an arm; but the one that's left is potent, and he's shaking Danny with it.

The plane reaches the top of its arc, and almost stalls; but Rafe noses it over again, toward the earth, only this time he has very little altitude. But the glow of the train is outshone by EVELYN STEWART.  She's one of ten young women, Army nurses, gathered at one end of the car as it rattles along the track. The other nurses are pretty and ripe -- maybe a bit too ripe.  Their lips painted bright red, their faces powdered, their spirits high. dialogue.raw_text: Maybe not.  But I need you to know.  I love you.  And I will come back.  I'll find a way.  And then we'll get a chance to know if what I felt the first moment I saw you, and every minute since then, is real.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Do one thing for me, before you go.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: She leads him onto the dance floor, and they dance, among the others, yet in a world apart from everyone else.  And then they stop while all the others move around them, and kiss the kind of kiss that lasts a lifetime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The nurses are entering the hotel.  Pilots are going in with them.  But Rafe and Evelyn stop on the street. A last kiss.  Their hands touch a final time, and then part. She moves inside the lobby, and looks out the glass doors as he walks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe and Danny stand on the platform.  Rafe's got his gear packed in a bag slung over his shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe glances once more toward the revolving doors from the station that lead onto the platform.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe sticks his hand out to Danny.  Danny knocks it away, and hugs him. Rafe steps onto the train, and it pulls away.  Rafe waves. Danny waves back and smiles, but he whispers like a prayer...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All aboard!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Didn't you say you told her not to come?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Then why are you looking for her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's a test.  If I asked her to come and she came, it wouldn't tell me anything. If I tell her not to come, and she comes...then I know she loves me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still a kid, ya know that?  Take care of yourself.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Give 'em hell, Rafe.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe finds a seat and sits down.  He's the only one in the car, and he's deeply alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny walks to one of the three revolving doors back into the station.  He takes the one on the far right.  As he passes through it, he doesn't see Evelyn rushing through the door on the left side.  She's told herself she wouldn't come, but couldn't help it, and now as she sees the last car of the train disappearing around the corner the pain of it all hits her. She stands on the empty platform, as lonely as Rafe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe and Evelyn travel in opposite directions, toward opposite ends of the earth...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: as Rafe boards a Canadian naval vessel headed into the North Atlantic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn and her fellow nurses ride the train through the American southwest.  The scenery outside the window is beautiful, but her thoughts are far away...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe's ship is in a convoy through the rough gray waters. The deck is loaded with military supplies bound for Britain. Rafe stands among the drab crates and seems oblivious to the rain, his thoughts on Evelyn. He looks toward the eastern horizon, where his ship is heading.  A deep, dark storm is brewing before them...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn stands on the deck of a ship headed in the opposite direction, on another ocean, the sky is clear, the breeze is warm, the light of a glowing sunset bathes her face.  The
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: with them heading to different ends of the earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In the eternal dusk of England, everything is cold and gray. British fighter planes -- Spitfires and Hurricanes -- are surrounded by mechanics hurriedly ripping off bullet riddled fuselage panels and digging into overworked aircraft engines. Rafe walks across the tarmac, still carrying his duffel bag. He moves up behind a slim, pale BRITISH AIR COMMANDER who is surveying engine damage on one of the Spitfires.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe salutes as the Air Commander turns and then returns the salute, with his left arm -- his right arm is gone.  Rafe freezes at the sight, reminded of Danny's father.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rafe McCawley, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On loan from Colonel Doolittle, is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's me, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Good on you, then, Rafe McCawley.  We'll get you situated in some quarters, and then introduce you to the equipment you'll be flying.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you're patching up bullet holes right here on the runway, maybe we should skip the housekeeping and get right to the planes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Are all the Yanks as anxious as you are to get yourself killed, Lieutenant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not anxious to die, Sir, anxious to matter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Spitfire sits on the runway, and it's badly mangled -- a string of bullet holes punched through at mid-fuselage; a shot-off chunk of wingtip; but most striking is the blood still splattered over the inside of the cockpit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He walks away, leaving Rafe to stare at the bloody cockpit.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Good lad.  Didn't die till he'd landed and shut down his engine.  Welcome to the war.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn and the nurses enter the base, riding in two jeeps. As they stop at the gate, the guards look at them, especially Evelyn in the lead jeep; one guard mumbles to the other -- GUARD I've died and gone to heaven. The guards lift the bar and smile at the nurses.  The jeeps drive through.  The nurses are loving this island paradise already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Barbara slides on a new pair of sunglasses with plastic palm trees glued on the sides, and calls back to the guards as the jeeps pull away -- BARBARA See ya on the beach, boys!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You know the ratio of men to women on this island?  Four-thousand...to one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: As the other nurses happily unpack, Evelyn leaves and crosses the grass in the drenching sunshine.  We follow her into -- INT.  BASE HOSPITAL - DAY She finds a small, immaculately clean hospital, twenty beds with luminous white sheets, all empty. Then she notices the view.  It's of Pearl Harbor, with the entire American Pacific fleet riding at anchor.  Battleships all in a row.  Aircraft carriers too, in perfect stillness on the aqua blue water with a white sand bottom.  The view is expansive and beautiful. The sound of an approaching fighter plane with wing guns firing as we -- CUT TO:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe, in the middle of an aerial dogfight, throws his Spitfire into a tight turn, swinging around to fire again into a squadron of Messerschmidts; they outnumber the British planes, and they're tougher and faster.  Rafe darts through their line, machine guns blazing. One of the Spitfires in Rafe's squadron has taken hits in the engine compartment and is sputtering, losing power, its pilot, NIGEL, frantic as the German planes swarm into finish him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe slams his control stick hard right and goes into a power dive at one of the Messerschmidts.  Rafe's bullets chew up its cockpit and the plane goes into a fast corkscrew spiral, down into the water. Rafe instantly climbs again.  Nigel, in the moment of safety Rafe has bought him, bails out, his chute blossoming and carrying him toward the water.  The OTHER BRITISH PILOTS are impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe swings his plane right back at the Germans; he attacks them head on, just like he went at Danny, only this time he's firing his machine guns. And OVER THIS ferocious dogfight, we hear his letter to Evelyn...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Messerschmidt in Rafe's sights breaks apart with the stream of precise fire he pours into it, its prop flying into pieces, its disintegration accelerated by its airspeed. Before it completely comes apart, it explodes. Rafe goes into another tight turn, to get at them again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Rafe starts another attack we see him in the cockpit, in the trance of battle, as other Spitfires around him are getting shot out of the sky...as we -- DISSOLVE TO:
direction.name: direction

location: THE DARK SKIES OVER THE ENGLISH CHANNEL
result.heading: EXT.

dialogue.raw_text: I need help!  Someone get them off me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (into radio) Nigel's out!  I'll call in the position! (to himself) That Yank is bloody good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear Evelyn... It is cold here.  So cold, in a way that goes deep into your bones.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not easy making friends.  Two nights ago I drank a beer with a couple of the R.A.F. pilots -- beer's the only thing here that isn't cold -- and yesterday both of them got killed...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn, receiving the letter at mail call. She sits on the grass under a palm tree, in paradise, reading his letter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: There is one place I can go to find warmth, and that is to think of you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn is off duty, and wears a light cotton dress.  She's let her hair down, and her skin has the sheen of light sweat in the tropical heat. The restaurant is barely more than a shelter of palm wood posts with a frond roof, and it looks out over the harbor. Evelyn sits alone.  She's brought writing paper.  As the Hawaiian waiter serves her an icy tropical ambrosia with chunks of pineapple and a fresh plumeria flower floating at the rim of the glass, she lifts her pen. But before she can start to write, three naval officers move over to her table from the bar.  They're out of uniform too, wearing garish tropical shirts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The guys look at each other, impressed that she could tell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He shows her the tattoo of an anchor on his forearm.  Evelyn looks away from them, toward the harbor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His friends start to pull him away, but Evelyn's eyes flare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They leave, shaking their heads.  Evelyn picks up her pen, and writes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She looks toward the sunset now; then she writes again...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A woman beautiful as you shouldn't be sitting alone.  Buy you a drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you...Ensign.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ensign!  Smart too!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So how about that drink?  Or dinner?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, but...I really want to be alone right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Want to see something long and hard?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry.  I've got a letter to write.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cold bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you say?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I said you're cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cold?  No, I'm just thinking about a war. And maybe you should be too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear Rafe... It's strange to be so far from you in body, and so close to you in spirit.  But if our spirits really give our bodies life, then you should know this:  Every night I look at the sunset, and try to draw the last ounce of heat from its long day...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe brings his battered plane in for a landing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe sits on his cot, reading her letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe is startled as the Air Commander appears beside his bunk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe nods, glad to hear the news.  The Commander starts to walk away, then turns back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Commander salutes, with his left hand.  And Rafe salutes too -- with his left hand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...and send it from my heart to yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Air-Sea Rescue picked up Nigel.  He'll be back with us tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Some of us look down on the Yanks for not yet joining this war.  I'd just like to say that if there are many more back home like you, God help anyone who goes to war with America.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  ESTABLISHING THE WHITE HOUSE - WASHINGTON D.C. - DAY The White House looks somehow whiter and purer in the glow of
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: and other advisors sit around the polished table -- all males, in suits and in uniforms.  The door opens, and the men all stand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: appears, in a wheelchair, pushed by a huge black valet, GEORGE.  The President's legs are shriveled, braced with the iron supports that attach to his shoes and are apparent beneath the cloth of his pin-striped pants.  From the waist up Roosevelt is heavily muscled, powerful, and handsome even in his little spectacles.  The valet rolls him to the head of the table; he's speaking even before he settles in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They sit, as one.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Please be seated, gentlemen.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Churchill and Stalin are asking me what I'm asking you:  How long is America going to pretend the world is not at war?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've increased supply shipments to them, Mr. President, and we're losing merchant vessels every day.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shift in every destroyer and anti- aircraft weapon you can find.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, our Pacific Fleet is already down to almost nothing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gentlemen, at this moment the nation of Hungry has a larger military then the United States.  We have no choice but to draw from whatever we can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  ESTABLISHING TOKYO - JAPAN - NIGHT INT.  JAPANESE HIGH COMMAND - NIGHT The Conference Room is similar to that of the White House. But this table is low and all the men sit on the floor.  And there are no civilians here; Japan is now a nation ruled by its warriors. The last man to enter the room and take his place is ADMIRAL YAMAMOTO.  Harvard educated, Yamamoto is an object of veneration and suspicion among the men of the war council. Yamamoto bows, sits, and looks across the table at his friend Genda, who can't hide his fear.  Yamamoto glances to the far end of the table where NISHIKURA, chief of the War Council, sits glowering.  (Their discussion is in Japanese, with subtitles.)
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He motions to OYAMA, an intelligence analyst, who opens a file and lays out pictures of Roosevelt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yamamoto makes a low grunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The members of the war council are so pleased with Yamamoto that they bow to him.  Only Genda keeps his eyes raised long enough to see the sadness in Yamamoto's face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So you join us, Admiral.  Some of us thought your education at an American university would make you too weak to fight the Americans.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If knowledge of opponents and careful calculation of danger is taken as weakness then I have misunderstood what it means to be Japanese.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The time has come to strike!  Or to sit and let the Americans cut off our oil and our future.  I know what you whisper to the others, Yamamoto -- that the Americans are strong.  Yet look at their leader.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Franklin Roosevelt.  Born into great wealth.  Fifteen years ago, he was stricken with polio.  Now he cannot walk, or even stand without help. Photographers will not take pictures of him in his chair; Americans do not wish to know how weak their President is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You have something to say, Yamamoto?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Council knows I have opposed fighting the Americans.  No matter how great our resolve, they have resources beyond ours. If we must go to war, there is only one way -- deal them a blow from which it will take them years to recover.  In that time we can conquer all of the Pacific, and they will have no choice but to ask for peace.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You see us as capable of such a blow?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Americans themselves have made it possible.  We will annihilate them in a single attack -- at Pearl Harbor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Danny Walker and his pilot buddies have just arrived; they enter the barracks, talking happily.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny has stopped before the others; now all of them see that the other pilots who inhabit this air base are still in their beds, sleeping off hangovers.  They wear Hawaiian shirts; they haven't shaved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny pauses for a moment, then shouts -- DANNY Drop your cocks and grab your socks, boys!  The terror of the skies are here! The sleeping pilots groan, and cover their heads with their pillows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: One guy sits up in bed, his hair pointing every direction of the compass, his tongue working as if to wipe a terrible taste from his mouth.  As his feet dangle over the side of the bunk and one of them touches the floor, a sensation reaches his sotted brain; he raises that foot to look at its bottom, and finds a new tattoo, on the sole of his foot; he blinks as if trying to remember how it got there. Danny moves over to him, and dubs him with a name, COMA.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma is one of those drunks who speak as if he's always about to burp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma emits a pukey, toxic burp that has Danny and his buddies wincing back from the fumes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The question soaks through to Coma's brain.  His right hand points...and his left hand points...in different directions. His hands float around in the air until finally both of them are indicating the same direction, behind his back.  In the bunk beyond Coma's is another drunk pilot in a Hawaiian shirt...and to judge by the shapely bronzed leg that protrudes from under his damp sheet, there's a woman with him too. Danny and his buddies are speechless -- except for Red Strange.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma's head drifts forward slowly; they think for a moment he's looking for something under the bed.  Then he pukes. Danny leaps back from the splatter, and marches out of the barracks; his friends follow.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Hey!  What is this, the planes all bunched up like that?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well guys...I reckon there's just one thing to do...

direction.raw_text: Danny and the pilots are in Hawaiian shirts, their party in full swing.  A bucket-sized hollowed-out volcano sits in the middle of the table, with twelve straws emerging from the crater.  It's full of booze -- or was; Danny and the other guys are pulling heartily at the straws, and they gurgle as the last liquid is sucked dry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma is sitting there with them, beside Red.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everybody's having a ball, the new arrivals fitting right in with the others.  Danny's a bit off to himself, lost in his own thoughts.  Billy and Anthony are doing the hula to the Hawaiian music playing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma stands and starts demonstrating, explaining the gestures of his hula.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coma's really into his dance, his hands over enormous imaginary breasts; but as he turns toward the windows -- COMA A more beautiful girl walks by... The guys see Evelyn passing on the other side of the street, gorgeous in the sunshine.  Coma's hands start squeezing the imaginary breasts of his hula.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny moves up to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny's hand is suddenly around Coma's larynx.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny releases him and Coma staggers back to the table to nuzzle up to one of the straws of the mai-tai volcano. Danny looks out the window again and sees Evelyn's beautiful form disappear around the corner, on her way back to the base hospital.  Danny moves back to the table, and as two burly Hawaiian waiters set another full loaded mai-tai volcano onto the center of the table, he picks up a glass and dips it full of the potent liquid.  He shouts to the whole room -- DANNY I'm a better pilot than any son-of-a- bitch on this island!  So I'm the one to say this!  Here's to Rafe McCawley!  A better pilot...and a better man...than me. The other pilots drink up -- from glasses or from straws.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny drains the whole glass at one chug, and slams it down onto the table.  Then he blinks, puts a hand on his stomach, and frowns.  Coma recognizes the look.

direction.raw_text: Danny bends at the waist; his head obscured by the table.

direction.raw_text: is Commander of the American Pacific Fleet. Two members of his staff are standing uncomfortably in front of him, having delivered a message from the Joint Chiefs of Staff.

dialogue.raw_text: ...transfer twelve more destroyers to Atlantic Fleet, and all the available anti-aircraft weaponry?!  Washington has gone insane!

dialogue.raw_text: We've done what you ordered, Admiral, and war gamed the likely outcome of a Japanese attack against each of our major bases in the Pacific.  Wake, Guam, Midway, the Philippines.  In each case, we lose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You left out Hawaii.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pearl Harbor can't be attacked effectively from the air.  It's too shallow for an aerial torpedo attack. Pearl Harbor's safe.  It's everywhere else that we're vulnerable.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Step up surveillance of Japanese communications.  They're gonna do something somewhere.  I can feel it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A seaplane takes tourists on an excursion above Pearl Harbor and around the island of Oahu.  One Japanese tourist shoots pictures rapidly...first of the ships as seen from overhead; then he leans to the other side of the plane and shoots pictures of the airfield below them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another Japanese tourist hikes through the hills above Pearl Harbor.  He takes an excellent camera from his picnic basket, and shoots pictures.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: being carried down a hallway, into -- INT.  JAPANESE PLANNERS OFFICE - DAY The courier places the pictures onto the table in front of Yamamoto, Genda, and the other JAPANESE OFFICERS.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He moves to a diagram displayed on the wall -- a simple display showing water depth and ship displacement.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From a stand beside his diagram he takes a set of wooden fins, attached to a circular metallic band.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look at the ships -- all grouped.  Perfect targets!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And the planes!  They are -- what is that American expression?  Sitting geese?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sitting ducks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How can they be so foolish?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: They think no one would be stupid enough to attack them at Pearl Harbor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Or perhaps they think no one is capable. Look at this...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Pearl Harbor's depth of only forty feet makes them feel safe.  A torpedo dropped from an airplane plunges to one hundred feet before it can level off.  That is a conventional torpedo.  But we have been experimenting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Wooden fins.  We are testing them tomorrow.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Yamamoto and his planners have flown to a quiet Japanese island, sunlit and pleasant.  They are gathered on the shore of the island's natural harbor.  Wooden targets -- basically huge plank barriers -- are sunk into the water like ships at anchor.  A squadron of Japanese planes zooms overhead, taking up attack positions.

direction.raw_text: Coming out of the blustery skies at the end of another deadly day, a squadron of Spitfires chirps in for landings.  The planes are shot up and battered. He taxis to a stop, and is met by IAN, a Scottish mechanic, who is dismayed at the state of the plane.

direction.raw_text: It's dark, but there are breaks in the clouds, giving way to patches of light from a full moon.  The squadron of Spitfires tightens up for battle. Rafe is positioned just right of the squad leader; he sees planes breaking out of the dark clouds ahead.

location: THE AIR BATTLE OVER THE CHANNEL
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: The Spitfires' bullets rip into the pilot and also kill the nose gunner; the bomber dips as the copilot struggles to take control.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As he streaks past, Rafe sees the bomber wobble in the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe throws his plane into an ultra-tight, high speed turn, right between the tails of the leader German group and the noses of the second.  His turn is so tight that the plane flexes with the g-force. Rafe comes out of his turn ahead of the Squad Leader, and races back up through the formation of German bombers, moving above them where their weapons and armaments are the weakest. He stitches a trail of bullets from tail to nose of the wounded lead bomber; it begins to smoke. The second Spitfire, the Squad Leader's, takes fire from the other German bombers, and shears off, heading through the smoke of the plane Rafe has on the ropes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe does a half-loop and half-spin, to bring him around to face the bombers again.  This time the g-force of the turn pops an oil line inside Rafe's cockpit; hot, pressurized oil begins to spray everywhere -- all over Rafe, his controls, and worst of all, over the inside of his cockpit glass. He wipes at the oil with his hands and that just smears it and makes it worse. His wingman sees him veering away from the bombers...and sees the German fighters moving up to meet him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We've got him hurt, stay on him!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We've got him going!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: McCawley!  Get to the clouds!  Get into the clouds!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: is flying blind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His problems are just beginning; the fluid is dripping down onto his cockpit's corroded electrical wiring; the fluid causes an arc...a spark...and suddenly a fire is spreading through Rafe's plane. He grabs his fire extinguisher and triggers a cloud that snuffs the fire but fills the entire cockpit with choking smoke; between that and the smeared fluid on his glass, he can't see a thing. And the Messerschmidts are swarming over him. Rafe's wingman dives in, raking the German planes as he passes. Rafe tries to open his cockpit cover to clear the smoke, but it's jammed; he pulls out his .45 pistol and BLAM!  BLAM!
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I can't see the clouds!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: !  He blows out the glass; the smoke clears enough for him to take a breath and try to see.  He fights the stick, but the plane won't respond. The Messerschmidts rake him again, bullets riddling his engine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe's plane descends, ever faster, passing through clouds, then clear air again.  The Squad Leader tries to chase and cover him, but Rafe's dropping fast, and still isn't out of the plane as the Germans dive on him again, firing. Rafe's Spitfire hits the broken fog over the water -- the Squad Leader loses sight of it for a moment -- and then the plane hits, splashing and exploding all at once. The Squad Leader winces, and ducks into the clouds as he reports on his radio...

dialogue.raw_text: Get out of there, McCawley!  Get out of there!

direction.raw_text: The sailors have assembled on deck for the ship's heavyweight championship fight, a contest made more interesting to the sailors because one of the combatants is white and the other is black. The battle is more toughness than technique.  The guys throwing haymakers and shoving each other around the roped area, as their shipmates cheer and make wild bets.  The white guy digs a punch deep into the black guy's ribs, and the black guy slams a double left hook into the white guy's belly, making him back up and say -- WHITE BOXER You hit hard -- for a cook. The black guy rushes the white guy, only to catch a right cross that wobbles his knees and makes him stagger, with a fresh cut over his right eye.  The white guy now rushes in, and the black guy (his name is DORIE MILLER) throws an upper cut that drops his opponent like a sack of rocks. The sailors cheer wildly.  Dorie steps back, and rubs his glove across his brow.  It's really bleeding now.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I left my Mama and joined the Navy to be a man.  They made me a cook -- and not even that, really -- I clean up after the other sailors eat.  I shine the officer's shoes.  In two years, they've never even let me fire a gun.

direction.raw_text: Dorie walks away, down the path between the palm trees.  She watches him go, and then is transfixed by someone else coming, silhouetted by the light of the setting sun.  She can't make out his face, but he's wearing a pilot's dress uniform, and coming to her right out of the warm orange sunset that she has stared at so many times.  Her heart slams against her ribs; she takes a few steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She moves toward him, and he draws near her, walking slowly. And then she sees his face... It's Danny.  His face as sad as death itself. And even before he tells her, she knows.

dialogue.raw_text: ...Rafe...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lieutenant... I'm Danny Walker.  I'm Rafe McCawley's best friend.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Were.  Isn't that what you mean?  Were. Because he's dead, isn't he?  And that's why you've come.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn and Danny sit on the bench, with a sweeping view of the harbor and the lights winking on all around it as the sun settles beyond the horizon.  Evelyn is stoic, numb; Danny is the one who is struggling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn nods, still staring away from Danny.  This pierces Danny; he looks away, struggling not to let the emotions pull him completely under.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She stares into the distance.  He stands and puts his hand on top of hers, as much for his comfort as for hers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since she's still not looking at him, he starts to move away. When he reaches the turn in the path, he looks back, and sees her figure in the gathering darkness.  She's begun to break down; and as he watches, her whole body starts convulsing, and she doubles up in shattering grief. Danny can't just stand there; he moves back to her, and puts a hand on her shoulder.  He sits beside her again, and suddenly she turns to him and sobs upon him.  Danny wraps her gently in his arms, and then he breaks down, having found the first place he can truly grieve.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Before Rafe left, he asked me to be the one to tell you, if it happened.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rafe's folks had a crop dusting business, owned their own planes.  Real straight, frugal.  My father was the town drunk. Went to sleep one night on the railroad tracks and was still there when the Dawn Express came along.  Rafe and I were the only ones at the funeral.  He took me back to his house, and I never left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You were more like brothers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I taught him to drink beer.  He taught me how to fly.

dialogue.raw_text: I understand why Rafe loved you.  You're as strong as he was.

direction.raw_text: The Japanese have constructed a replica of Pearl Harbor on their practice island; erecting new target barriers and silhouettes of the various ships anchored at Pearl.  Streams of Japanese planes skim overhead in practice bombing runs, dropping dummy torpedoes and bombs.  From a control platform erected on the beach, Yamamoto and Genda oversee it all.

Between these two is something they call the Vacant Sea.  If I were the Japs, I'd send a task force there.  You could hide the entire land mass of Asia in the Vacant Sea, and nobody would know.

direction.raw_text: Evelyn walks out of the hospital.  She's still wearing her lei.  The sun is going down in a spectacular sunset. She stares at the orange glow at the edge of the world.  She breathes in the sea air, and tries to breathe out the sadness.  The water of the harbor laps close to where she stands, the sunset polishing its surface. She takes the lei from her neck, plucks a single flower, and holds it like the rose Rafe once gave her.  Then she tosses the rest of the lei into the ocean and watches it float away, as the sun sinks behind the horizon.

dialogue.raw_text: You're Walker, right?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was a nice little stunt you pulled, buzzing the base.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You liked that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeah.  I liked it so much I'm cutting you out of the squadron.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't buy that hot dog shit.  So you and your buddies are gonna transfer your planes up to Haleiwa.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hale-what?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You'll love it.  No base, no bars, just lots of sun and aircraft maintenance.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sir, I -- COLONEL Too late for apologies, Walker.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wasn't gonna apologize, Sir.  I was just gonna say it was worth it to feel like a real pilot again, even if it was only for five seconds.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Danny and Evelyn are having coffee at the base canteen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's been lost in his own thoughts of Rafe; now he notices the tears welling up in her eyes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: How's everything?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We got some soldiers in traction from a jeep accident, but it's quiet.  Except for the occasional fighter plane buzzing us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That might not have been such a good idea.  They're making us fly out of a half-paved airfield.  The real punishment is that I won't be back to the barracks till it's too late for dinner or coffee. So I guess it's goodbye for awhile.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was just thinking that war is a series of goodbyes.  Do you think that's why we're meeting.  To help us say goodbye to Rafe?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I swore not to talk about him tonight, but there's all this stuff I think I ought to tell you, that he didn't get a chance to.  Rafe was...he was lonely.  He had such high expectations of himself that he always felt empty.  The week he met you he told me he felt his heart had always lived in winter, and for the first time in his life he has seen the spring.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He told me he didn't want to leave me with regret.  Now that's all I have.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, have you seen Pearl Harbor at night?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well...sure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: From the air?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: takes off from the remote airfield, lit only by the full moon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn sits on Danny's lap, like Rafe sat in his Daddy's lap years before.  Danny flies easily, the cockpit open, his arms slipped under hers. The sky above them is startlingly clear; a billion stars dancing around a full moon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He spins the plane in an easy half turn, inverting their heads above Pearl Harbor, gorgeous in the moonlight, the battleships aglow, the moon reflected in the peaceful water, embraced by the island of Oahu.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So beautiful!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hang on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The P-40 soars easily in and settles to earth.  Danny shuts down the engine.  Danny carefully removes the harness around her.  She looks overhead.  The stars are still bright above them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She turns in his lap, and looks at him.  Their eyes connect. Tentatively, almost reluctantly, they kiss.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't realize until tonight that I've stopped wanting to live.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The POV of someone moving through the gathering darkness approaches the hospital. The lights from within the hospital, and the pristine white beds beneath those lights, give the place a kind of glow, where Evelyn moves alone and beautiful, like a ballerina in a giant's jewel box. Now we see the shoulders of the figure, from behind, and can tell that it is a man in uniform, but at first we can't tell who.  He's standing dead still, transfixed in watching Evelyn through the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn moves to her desk, and sits down.  She looks at the calender turning back to October, where she wrote on the square of October 22, "Order supplies" -- she counts the weeks from then to today, December 6.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see the full figure of the man watching her.  And now we see his face.  It is Rafe. His left hand is bandaged, but he is very much alive -- though seeing Evelyn has taken his breath, and even seems to have robbed him of the power to move.  His eyes pick up every detail of her -- her face...her hands. And as Rafe watches Evelyn, he has the SUDDEN JOLTS OF SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACKS...punctuated by fragments of the letter she wrote to him, and INTERCUT with Rafe in the present, watching Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: IN SUBLIMINAL FLASHBACK, RAFE'S SPITFIRE, crippled and trailing smoke, passing through a patch of cloud as Rafe hurls himself from the cockpit and jerks the ripcord of his chute.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dearest Rafe --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: ...Rafe's face winces with the memory, and he rivets his eyes on Evelyn, as if to force himself to know that this moment is real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ...RAFE LANDS IN THE WATER, and the shock of its coldness travels up his body faster than his body sinks into the water.  He's cloaked in the fog; his parachute, pushed by the wind, is pulling him along face down.  He fights with the straps, flips himself over, and pulls the release... But he's still in desperate trouble; in his flying clothes, his heavy leather jacket soaking with sea-water, he's going down; his body sinks beneath the surface...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...Every sunset...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe's chest trembles... Is it from the memory of the frozen water, from the emotion of seeing Evelyn again -- or both?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Below the surface of the North Sea, Rafe's body drifts, but he fights his way back up...he kicks off his shoes, sheds the jacket, strips off his pants and starts tying the cuffs into knots. Then, in a CUT, he is floating in the water, his pants turned into a makeshift life preserver, his body shaking convulsively from the cold. Then in another CUT we see him after he's been in the water for so long that his body no longer trembles; he's lost consciousness.  He has no strength, no will to live... His face settles into the water...his body slips from his preserver, and drifts beneath the surface...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: ...gather it's heat into my heart, and send it to you...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe beneath the surface... His eyes come open. From his POV beneath the water, he sees something above the surface.  It's only in his mind, but that makes it no less real...an orange glow, the warmth of the sunset, and her face above the surface... His limbs come to life, and he fights his way up, breaking the surface.  The whole sea around him is dark and empty, but he grabs his makeshift preserver and holds on for dear life...and for Evelyn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe stares through the window, at Evelyn, but he can't go in.  He backs away from the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Japanese-American MESSAGE BOY parks his motorbike outside and enters the barracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny rises from his bunk and accepts the telegram.  As the message boy leaves, Danny reads... The news he learns stuns him...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Daniel Walker?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe is still lost in thought.  He hears steps running up -- and sees Danny -- who spots him at the same moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rafe!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn puts away the calender.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe is sitting at the bench, his head down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - Evelyn on the path; she sees someone on the bench, his form hauntingly familiar.  He hears her, and looks up. It's Rafe. From Evelyn's POV, the whole world spins.  She faints. Rafe jumps to catch her before she slams to the ground.  He gathers her into his arms, and she looks up into his face. He's real, very real.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's trembling, shaking.  He lifts her to her feet, and moves her to the bench.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks toward the horizon, when the last light of day fades to black.  There's something he thinks about saying, and doesn't.  Then...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He looks at her, then looks down again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At these words, she looks at him for a long, long moment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sees the troubled look on her face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She nods; she can't even say it.  Rafe's dying inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny runs up, through the darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe and Danny stare at each other; Danny hesitates, looking from Rafe to Evelyn, wondering what they've said.  Then Rafe looks at Evelyn, and picks up the look on her face.  In that moment he puts it all together.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny's speechless, and for a moment Evelyn is too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He puts up a hand, to silence her, and walks away suddenly. Evelyn and Danny are left frozen.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Evelyn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I sent telegrams, I guess the military traffic held them up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why were you sitting here, instead of...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I saw you, I couldn't go in, I...just stood there wondering if you knew.  You looked...sad, and I had to sit down a minute.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How did you?...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Survive?  I jumped in a patch of fog, and nobody could see me.  I hit the water hard.  And it was so...cold.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know how long I was in the water. A Norwegian freighter picked me up.  They were headed to Spain.  They docked in La Rota, right beside a German ship, and told me to stay hidden below.  I was afraid they'd turn me in, so I stole some clothes, jumped ship, and found a church, where the priest contacted the resistance, and got me on a freighter to New York.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I called my folks, then Colonel Doolittle.  The Colonel sent a man to pick me up.  They wanted to debrief me. I told the Colonel I needed to see somebody first, and he had a supply flight heading out in an hour. (beat) I've done a lot of talking.  You haven't said anything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm just...so amazed, so glad to know that you're okay.  You are okay, aren't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing that won't heal.  I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's been...so different, being so sure you were dead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm so sorry for what you must've gone through, but I'm back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe I've assumed too much.  Has something changed? (beat) I'm afraid to ask what.  And I'm afraid not to. (beat) Have you fallen in love?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's all right.  Danny always said I see things with my emotions instead of my eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not your fault, Rafe.  The letter I wrote you, they -- RAFE Don't worry about that.  Guys away from home, lonely, good-hearted women try to cheer them up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's not that I didn't mean everything I wrote.  It's just that -- I thought you were dead.  And now --
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're alive!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aw, God.  Oh my God.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rafe --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe stares out at the harbor, seeing nothing.  As he stands there alone and shattered, he has one more
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe is in the water of the North Sea; he seems dead, but his makeshift preserver is keeping his face above the surface. Something slides through the water and stops beside him; it's a dinghy, and behind it is a trawler. Hands grab Rafe and drag him onto the dinghy... In a QUICK CUT, Rafe's body is laid out on the deck of the trawler.  The crewmen think he's dead.  His body is stiff, his lips white; and they say so, in Norwegian... But one of the other crewmen notices a quiver in his eyelid, then quickly covers Rafe with his on wool peacoat and presses back an eyelid to see his pupils.  Rafe's white lips move. The crewmen realize he's trying to say something. And Rafe does utter something, barely audible; something the Norwegian crewmen don't understand.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Evelyn...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rafe struggles to bury that memory so far that he'll never feel it again.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He hugs her; their embrace earnest yet tingled with guilt, and Danny leave quickly.  Betty steps out of the nurses' quarters and hands Evelyn a telegram.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn knows it's the telegram from Rafe, to tell her he's alive.  Without opening it, she begins to cry, and hurries away from the barracks so the other nurses won't see.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry.  I'll find him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This came while you were gone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Danny crosses the tarmac toward the clustered P-40's.  He spots what he's looking for.  Sitting in the cockpit of one of the P-40's is Rafe.  Rafe won't look at him.  Danny climbs up on the wing, and sits down there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You'd always go sit in a plane whenever you were upset.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Upset?  Why should I be upset?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's go get a drink.  Unless you're scared to talk about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: - A Mai-Tai volcano clunks onto a table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Drink up.  Then we'll talk. Rafe takes the challenge, and takes a long pull on one of the straws.  Red, Anthony, Billy, and several others enter the bar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They rush the table...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Rafe?!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: They're all drinking, and the whole bar is rocking.  Rafe uses glasses to show his buddies tactics.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The last words bring the group to silence.  The other guys drift away, to give them room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The waitress delivers four bottles to the table.  Rafe takes a slow sip, then stares at Danny.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny takes a long pull of beer, and Rafe does the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rafe nods thoughtfully, and sets down his beer.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: They'll go under you because their planes are faster, then they run so you can't catch 'em.  But then they'll come around and take you from behind -- like some Americans will.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why be sorry?  That's what you feel, it's better to come out with it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I didn't mean it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure you did.  So come on.  Say what you think.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Waitress!  Four beers!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You don't wanna put beer over mai-tai.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you can't keep up, don't drink yours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We gotta face some facts here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What facts are those?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I understand how it could happen.  I know why any guy would love her.  And I can't blame you that it happened.  You thought I was dead, she was grieving, you were trying to help her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was grieving too.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeah, right.  Anyway, you didn't know.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what are you saying?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm saying now you do know.  So it's time for you to fuck off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You left her.  How's that for a fact?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's this for a fact?  I loved her first.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You know, you're a lousy drinker. Drinking's supposed to make men feel bigger.  It only makes you stupid.  And weak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: !  He knocks Danny out of the chair, flat on his ass. Danny backhands the blood from the corner of his mouth.

direction.raw_text: He kicks Rafe in the back of the knee, then mule kicks him in the chest as he goes down, and the fight is on. The bar's bouncer, a big Samoan, moves over to break them up
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You want it, you got it.

direction.raw_text: but Anthony steps in his way.

direction.raw_text: The bouncer tosses Anthony aside, but before he can move in to interrupt the fight, Red breaks a lava volcano of Mai-Tai over the bouncer's skull.  The bartender picks up the phone to call the M.P.'s. Rafe and Danny are exchanging punches in the middle of the room.  Sailors sitting at the bar have swung around on their stools to watch the action.  The other pilots are wincing with the punches their friends exchange, and bobbing and weaving as if in the fight themselves.  A SAILOR tapes Billy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy hits him.  The whole bar erupts. Rafe and Danny are really having at it, fueled by so much emotion that nothing hurts.  They're on the floor now, trying to rip each other apart.  They struggle to their feet and Rafe manages to knee Danny in the balls.  Danny doubles over in pain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Without looking up, Danny lunges at Rafe, tackling him around the waist, driving him at the wall. But they don't hit the wall; they tumble through the back window of the bar -- not covered in glass, but fronds and wood -- and out into the back alley. They're lying there in the debris when they see the M.P. jeeps coming.  They drag each other to their feet, and run away.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Let 'em fight, they need it.

dialogue.raw_text: Is this a private fight or can anybody jump in?

dialogue.raw_text: That hurt?  I didn't think you had any balls.

direction.raw_text: on the bridge think they spot something.

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny has pulled his Buick convertible off the road; Rafe is bent over, his head out of frame; he's throwing up.  Danny's banged up from the fight and still drunk himself; he waits beside Rafe, who chokes out between heaves -- RAFE How come you're not pukin'?

direction.raw_text: Rafe doesn't seem to be listening; but Danny knows he is.

direction.raw_text: Rafe stands to face Danny; this is hard for Danny to say.

direction.raw_text: Danny slams his fist into Rafe's sick gut.  Rafe doubles over again, coughing, nothing left in his belly to come up. Rafe stand slowly, nodding as if he knows the punch was what he deserved.  Danny's about to apologize when once more Rafe knees him in the balls. Danny folds up, drops to his knees, and starts to retch.

direction.raw_text: Rafe crawls into the back seat of the car and passes out, Danny still collapsed at the side of the road.

dialogue.raw_text: I guess I'm used to it.  I've felt like throwing up every minute since you got back.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't blame her, Rafe.  It's not like you're thinking.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (between heaves) Fuck you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She loves you.  I know that.  And part of what she loves in me is how much of you she sees in me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We were both torn up.  I started dropping by to see her, because we understood what each other felt.  We'd have coffee and try not to talk about you, but we always would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She said I was so much like you.  I said, No, I'm not.  I'm like I am because of you, but I'm not you, not as good as you. Everybody else saw me as a loser with a big chip on his shoulder.  But you saw the better part of me, the part of me that could be like you, and changed me. You made me who I am.

dialogue.raw_text: How sweet.  Is that when you put the move on her?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's better.

dialogue.raw_text: I hope it is a destiny that will bring honor to our family, and if it requires my life I will sacrifice it gladly, if you can think of me and my hope to be a good servant of our nation, and a worthy son.  With love and devotion, Kazuyoshi.

It is a stirring sight for the Japanese; the pilots waiting in their cockpits, the officers watching from the bridge, the seamen on the flight deck. dialogue.raw_text: Captain, do you see that, in our wake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's a conning tower.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Could it be one of ours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's trying to follow us through the sub nets, into the harbor.  Sink the son of a bitch.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The deck gun barks, aimed toward the conning tower of the Japanese sub in the distance.  The first shot sails directly over the tower, missing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese sub commander sees, through his periscope, the flame erupt on the Ward's deck; he's being fired upon.  He snaps orders -- JAPANESE SUB CAPTAIN Dive!  Dive!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gunners snap in another shell and fire again.  It's a direct hit, the sub is ripped apart, it rolls over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Captain watches the sub sinking and snaps an order.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Fleet command, from destroyer Ward.  Have fired upon and sunk enemy submarine seeking to enter Pearl Harbor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  ESTABLISHING - RADAR STATION - PEARL HARBOR - DAWN INT.  RADAR STATION - PEARL HARBOR - DAWN There are two guys left in the room, yawning over their new radar equipment.  The Officer, ELLIS, checks his watch; it's a few minutes after seven a.m.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: His screen shows a huge cloud of blips, heading toward them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gets on the telephone.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Time to shut her down.  That was a good first session.  You'll get the hang of this new radar soon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you, Sir.  Hey...what's this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've never seen anything like that before.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The phone rings and an officer answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He covers the phone and tells his commander -- OFFICER Radar station has picked up a cloud of blips, coming in from the northeast. He switches on the radio, and tunes it to KGMB; hearing the Hawaiian music reassures him something...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Watch command... Coming from which direction?... Hold on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: is on early.  That means we've got a flight of B-17's coming in from the mainland, they use the radio music for a homing beacon.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dismayed, Ellis listens to the response from the headquarters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He and the private look again at the cloud of blips -- growing ever larger, and moving in fast.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, Sir. (he hangs up) They say don't worry about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Japanese formations are streaking through the sky.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese bombers, with three-man crews, are listening to the Hawaiian music of the radio station, using it for their homing beacon.  They look out and see the sunrise -- it's beautiful, and resembles the Japanese flag.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese scout plane is high in the air.  It radios -- SCOUT PLANE PILOT Harbor quiet.  Ships in place.  Carriers gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yamamoto is handed this message.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We have achieved surprise, but their carriers are not in port.  I don't like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We have a fighter screen up, in case we are attacked, Admiral.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We must go ahead.  This is our moment.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: .  ADMIRAL KIMMEL'S HOME - DAY The Admiral, dressed in his golf clothes, is leaving his home when a naval LIEUTENANT appears at his door.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Admiral, one of our destroyers reports sinking a sub on its way into Pearl.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Relay that to Washington...and cancel my golf game.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Kimmel enters his office, and is handed the latest dispatches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Any response from Washington?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nothing, Sir.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: A telegram, addressed to Admiral Kimmel, lands in the regular, not urgent, dispatch box.  The messenger handles it promptly, hopping on his motorbike to deliver it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese planes increase throttle and nose down, diving toward the surface, hurtling into attack mode.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The harbor lies quiet.  It's a sleepy Sunday morning. Children are playing, officers are stepping from their houses in their shorts to get the morning paper...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hawaiian Boy Scouts are hiking on a side of one of the mountains overlooking Pearl. Suddenly booming over the mountain, barely ten feet above the summit, comes a stream of planes. The boys are awed.  What is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: S - Between the approach of the Japanese planes, and sleepy Pearl Harbor...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The planes, in formation, their propellers spinning, their engines throbbing...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pearl Harbor, with the ships silent, their engines cold, their anchors steady on the harbor bottom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese submarines heading in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The American destroyers docking, instead of going out to search for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Another formation of Japanese bombers climbing high, into attack position.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese torpedo planes dropping down to the level of the ocean, their engines beginning to scream.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The American planes bunched on the airfields.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yamamoto and his staff huddle tensely, over their battle maps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: the second wave of planes is being brought up and loaded with munitions...the Japanese flag snaps tautly in the wind...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: American officers are laughing on the putting green near the club house, where the American flag droops from the flag pole, limply at peace.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: ON THE GOLD COURSE NEAR PEARL HARBOR,

direction.raw_text: The Japanese planes roaring down just over the wave tops of Pearl Harbor itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children playing in the early morning sun, looking up as they see the planes flash by.  The children look -- they've never seen this many, flying this low...but they are not alarmed, only curious. The images come faster and faster, the collision of Japan's determination and American's innocence...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Two sailors are standing on the deck, sharing a smoke, looking out over the quiet harbor.  One of them sees the first few planes streaking in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Something drops from the lead plane and splashes easily into the water; the plane banks away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A white streak runs through the water at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They watch it rush at them...then, a MASSIVE EXPLOSION!  It throws up a fifty foot wall of water, hurling the sailors and everything else on the deck into the sea.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look at that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's the Army again, practicing on us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Practice torpedoes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now listen, you'll hear a little thud when it hits the side of the ship.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The first wave of planes drop more torpedoes; they plunge
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: their wooden fins working perfectly, the torpedoes speeding to their targets... We see their AWESOME BLASTS against the anchored ships as the torpedoes hit home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Japanese LOW ALTITUDE BOMBERS come in; some drop their bombs directly into the ships; some skip their bombs across the water, the bombs glancing off the surface and then slamming the sides of battleships with tremendous explosions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sleeping sailors are thrown from their bunks; those already awakened run for their battle stations, and try to make it up to the deck; but there's no escape there, as...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Zero fighter planes strafe the ships, raking the decks and killing sailors with MACHINE GUN FIRE.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fire and smoke are turning everything into chaos.  some sailors rush to man the guns, they find the ammo boxes locked. Under the bombing and strafing, they find a wrench and start pounding on the lock, trying to break open the ammo box. Then they break open the lock -- and find the ammo box empty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs for the ladders, and is shot down before he gets there.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Shit!  I'll get some ammo!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The dive bombers scream in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bombs are hitting the deck.  Sailors are blown into the air and out into the oily water.  Nearby ships are catching fire; the flames spread out onto the oily water itself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorie Miller, the boxing champion/kitchen helper, is working picking up the breakfast trays when he feels the ship shudder.  The intercom comes alive -- INTERCOM Battle stations!  Battle stations!  This is not a drill! Men run to the ladders, and the shaking of the ship from a bomb blast tosses them off; Dorie's at the foot of the ladder when men fall back on top of him.
direction.name: direction

location: BELOW DECKS OF THE WEST VIRGINIA
result.heading: INT.

direction.raw_text: The Captain of the ship has reached the command bridge, where most of his staff is lying wounded from a bomb blast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: MORE TORPEDOES and BOMBS blast into the ship.  A big chunk of shrapnel tears into the Captain and rips his stomach open. The medics he was just directing to other men now run to him, as the men they were going to help have been blown apart.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Stay calm!  Find your positions.  Medics, get the wounded to sick bay!  Load and --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sailors run up from below and are gunned down and blasted down before they can reach their weapons. Dorie Miller emerges from below decks and sees the carnage, the confusion.  A bloody OFFICER grabs him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorie runs into the fire and smoke, toward the bridge.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Boy!  We need stretcher bearers on the bridge!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dorie arrives to see the medics crouched over the disemboweled Captain, who is still giving orders.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorie helps the medic lift the Captain to take him below.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Radio for air cover.  Organize the other medics.  Initiate fire control.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dorie carries the Captain down the ladder by himself, using one arm to climb and one to hold the Captain like a child's teddy bear.  When they reach the bottom the pain has grown too much for the Captain; he know's he's dying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorie puts him down; the medic jumps down the ladder and reaches the Captain, who tells him -- CAPTAIN OF THE WEST VIRGINIA Find my executive officer and tell him he's in command.  Tell him to fire the boilers and... He trembles in death throes...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's dead.  The Medic runs toward the ladder, reaches the hatch, and is blasted back to the bottom by an explosion overhead. Dorie runs for the ladder, and climbs out into hell.
direction.name: direction

location: BELOW DECKS OF THE WEST VIRGINIA
result.heading: INT.

dialogue.raw_text: Put me down here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Make sure the gunners have enough ammuni --
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Dorie emerges into even greater carnage and confusion.  A sailor, his body on fire, runs past and leaps into the oily water -- but it is in flames too. Then Dorie sees it:  an unmanned anti-aircraft gun.  He runs to it, through the strafing. The gun already has a belt of ammo in it -- apparently loaded by the gunner who lies beside it with his chest shot open. Dorie swings the business end of the gun toward the Zeros coming in out of the smoke, and he begins to fire. The Zeros keep coming and he keeps firing; nothing on earth will knock him from that gun.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn is up, dressed; her roommates are just stirring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Evelyn has stepped to the door when she hears a distant rumble and looks across the harbor to see smoke rising, ships taking hits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As she runs, Japanese planes are coming toward the base.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh my God... EVERYBODY TO THE HOSPITAL!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The men were sitting down to breakfast, but the machine gun bullets tearing up the outer walls have them clogging the doors, and it's so clogged they can't all get out. A steel bomb crashes through the roof and slams through the room, taking out tables and chairs before bouncing off the wall and coming to a stop.
direction.name: direction

location: THE MESS HALL AT HICKAM FIELD
result.heading: EXT.

direction.raw_text: trapped within the mess hall, see it stop without detonating.  They are bug-eyed, hearts stopped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The bomb detonated, blowing everything to bloody dust.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Dud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Evelyn reaches the hospital first and runs to the cabinet, withdrawing supplies. Barbara and Sandra appear at the far door, both terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She races into the hallway, the other two following.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Get everything out!  Bandages, sutures -- oh God, the men in traction... Come with me!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Four men from a jeep accident are lying in traction, their casted limbs roped in the air.  Evelyn runs in, grabbing a razor blade from the medical cabinet -- and telling Barbara and Sandra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bombs are falling outside, on the airfield this wing of the hospital faces.  Evelyn slices the traction ropes of a man with both legs broken; ignoring his groans, she rolls him out of the bed and covers him with the mattress.  The other nurses follow her lead.  The bombs are coming toward the hospital ward; Evelyn finishes with the fourth man and covers him and herself with the mattress, just as a bomb craters outside the window. The nurses and patients look up after the explosions have passed; there's a chunk of smoking shrapnel lying on the springs of the bunk where the last man had been lying.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Cut them down, and take cover!!  Hurry!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Japanese low-altitude bombers, with Zero escorts, zoom in over the field, blasting the clusters of American warplanes, whole squadrons taken out with one bomb. The mechanics and pilots, caught in the open, run from the strafing.  The Zeros rake them down with machine gun fire. It's carnage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sammy, the amateur photographer, is leaving his house for a morning of working his "Pictures of Paradise" business, when he sees the Japanese formations rumbling toward Pearl.  He races back inside.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He fishes into his drawer for a film camera, and digs out cans of film, struggling to load it as he runs back out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The pilots of Danny's squadron have returned from their night of drinking and brawling and are crashed on their bunks.  Red stirs and staggers toward the head; he bumps into the wall, backs up like a wind-up toy and lurches blindly forward again, into -- INT.  BARRACKS - THE HEAD - DAY Red sleepwalks to the urinals and unleashes a marathon piss stream, still in his sleep.  A rumble penetrates his brain, and his eyes come open a fraction.  Through the window slits above the urinals, he can see a cloud of Japanese planes rushing past. He squeezes his eyes shut, and looks again; the planes start bombing the distant hangers. Red pisses along the wall as he races to the barracks, trying to get his pecker back into his drawers.  He shouts to the sleeping guys -- RED Th-th-th-th-th- He slaps his face with both hands, and stomps his feet...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He still can't get it out, can't wake them; bursting with frustration, he suddenly blasts out singing -- RED (singing) The Jaaaps!!  The Jaaaps!! He's belting it like a baritone in a bizarre opera.  His friends stir; what the hell?  Red points outside and tries to talk, but now he can't mutter a syllable.  The guys hear the explosions, and realize...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Th-th-th-th-Dammit!  Th-th-th-
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The pilots stagger out, half drunk, half dressed.  Seeing what's happening, they race toward the flight line, where the clustered American planes are blowing up in groups, and the pilots are knocked to the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Billy jumps to his feet and starts to run toward a cluster of fighters that hasn't gone up yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Anthony tries to grab him and drag him back to earth but he misses; Billy gets a few steps before the fire from a strafing Zero catches up to him; his friends watch in horror as Billy gets shorter as he runs; the Zero's machine gun fire is sawing his legs off from the feet up. Billy falls, legless but still alive; then a bomb falls almost on top of him, sending body parts over the pilots. Their innocence, like America's, is gone in that moment.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Goddamn Japs!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Billy!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Danny and Rafe are in Danny's Buick, hung over and asleep, Danny in front, Rafe in back, and they're a miserable sight
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: their shirts ripped, blood dried in a leak trail from one side of Rafe's nose and the corner of Danny's mouth. The rumble of planes moving overhead makes them stir; the rumble grows huge, as the shadows of a massive formation makes the sunlight flicker.  Danny and Rafe squint up, their heads pounding, and realize what they're seeing.  Suddenly their headaches are gone, and Danny's gunning the Buick down the road, toward the base.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny blasts through the main gate; the guards are too busy taking cover and haven't even closed the barrier. He races to the tarmac, where some of the planes are still undamaged.  Rafe is out the door before the car stops rolling, and Danny's right behind him. They're running toward a cluster of fighters, when it goes up with a bomb blast.  Rafe and Danny dive at each other; their first instinct is to cover their best friend with their own bodies. They look at each other on the ground.  They see machine gun bullets thudding into the planes on the flight line, and ripping along the walls of the buildings.  It's as if the whole Japanese airforce is attacking this one base, and not leaving a single plane airworthy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny sprints; Rafe follows.  Danny reaches a phone booth, and digs a dime from his pants.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Danny dials, as waves of bullets sweep the area, and more planes blow up on the flight line.  Rafe thinks he's lost his mind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He runs back toward the car; Rafe, in the nonsense of battle, reaches in to hang up the receiver, before Danny grabs him and leads him on a sprint to the car, as the phone booth shatters behind them from the strafing.
